hints_html:
Calculate the first and second derivatives of \(f(x)\) and set them equal to zero to find the critical points.

To fill in the rest of the tables, for each cell choose a point in the appropriate interval (which will partially be determined by the critical points you’ve already found). Plug it into the appropriate function/derivative to determine whether it is positive or negative. Save yourself some work - you don’t need to find the exact value, just whether it is positive or negative.
hints_latex:
Calculate the first and second derivatives of $f(x)$ and set them equal

appropriate interval (which will partially be determined by the critical
points you've already found). Plug it into the appropriate
function/derivative to determine whether it is positive or negative.
Save yourself some work - you don't need to find the exact value, just
whether it is positive or negative.
hints_raw:
Calculate the first and second derivatives of <math>f(x)</math> and set them equal to zero to find the critical points.
To fill in the rest of the tables, for each cell choose a point in the appropriate interval (which will partially be determined by the critical points you've already found).  Plug it into the appropriate function/derivative to determine whether it is positive or negative.  Save yourself some work - you don't need to find the exact value, just whether it is positive or negative.
question: B 02
sols_html:
Before taking derivatives, we will fill in the first table, by testing values in the two intervals listed.

Note that \(x^2 + 1\) will always be positive, so when calculating whether the function/derivatives are positive or negative, it is sufficient to look at the numerator as the denominator will always be positive.

  • \((-\infty, 0)\), test point \(x = -1\)

\[\begin{aligned} f(-1) = \frac{-1}{(-1)^2 + 1} = \frac{-1}{2} < 0\end{aligned}\]

  • \((0, \infty)\), test point \(x = 1\)

\[\begin{aligned} f(1) = \frac{1}{(1)^2 + 1} = \frac{1}{2} > 0\end{aligned}\]

So the first table should be filled in as:

[c]@llll@ & \((-\infty,0)\) & 0 & \((0,\infty)\)
\(f\)(x) & - & 0 & +

Proceeding to the second table, we will calculate the first derivative using the quotient rule:

\(f'(x) = \frac{1*(x^2 + 1) - x(2x)}{(x^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{1 - x^2}{(x^2 + 1)^2}\)

Setting equal to zero and solving for x gives:

\(\displaystyle 0 = 1 - x^2\)

That is, \(\displaystyle x = -1\), \(\displaystyle x = 1\). These are then our values for \(c_1\) and \(c_2\). We can now test points in the three intervals labeled in the table.

  • \((-\infty, -1)\), test point \(x = -2\)

\[\begin{aligned} f'(-2) = \frac{1 - (-2)^2}{((-2)^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{-3}{25} < 0\end{aligned}\]

  • \((-1,1)\), test point \(x = 0\)

\[\begin{aligned} f'(0) = \frac{1 - (0)^2}{((0)^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{1}{1} > 0\end{aligned}\]

  • \((1, \infty)\), test point \(x = 2\)

\[\begin{aligned} f'(2) = \frac{1 - (2)^2}{((2)^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{-3}{25} < 0\end{aligned}\]

Filling in the table should look like this:

[c]@llllll@ & \((-\infty,c_1)\) & c1 & \(\displaystyle (c_1,c_2)\) & c2 & \((c_2,\infty)\)
\(f\)’(x) & - & 0 & + & 0 & -

Finally, we compute the second derivative, again using the quotient rule:

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) &= \frac{-2x(x^2 + 1)^2 - (1-x^2)(2)(x^2 + 1)(2x)}{(x^2 + 1)^4} \\ &= \frac{-2x(x^2 + 1) -(1-x^2)(4x)}{(x^2 + 1)^3} \\ &= \frac{-2x^3 -2x -4x+4x^3}{(x^2 + 1)^3} \\ &= \frac{2x^3 -6x}{(x^2 + 1)^3} \\ &= \frac{2x(x^2-3)}{(x^2 + 1)^3}\end{aligned}\]

Again solving for where \(\displaystyle f''(x) = 0\) we have

\(\displaystyle 0 = 2x(x^2 - 3)\)

which yields critical points of \(x = -\sqrt{3}, x = 0\) and \(x = \sqrt{3}\), which will be \(r_1, r_2, r_3\) respectively. When testing points in each of the four intervals of the table, it is worth noting that \(\sqrt{3}\) is somewhere between 1 and 2.

  • \((-\infty, -\sqrt{3})\), test point \(x = -2\)

\[\begin{aligned} f''(-2) = \frac{2(-2)((-2)^2 -3)}{({-2}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{-4}{5^3} < 0\end{aligned}\]

  • \((-\sqrt{3}, 0)\), test point \(x = -1\)

\[\begin{aligned} f''(-1) = \frac{2(-1)((-1)^2 - 3)}{({-1}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{4}{2^3} > 0\end{aligned}\]

  • \((0, \sqrt{3})\), test point \(x = 1\)

\[\begin{aligned} f''(1) = \frac{2(1)((1)^2 -3)}{({1}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{-4}{2^3} < 0\end{aligned}\]

  • \((\sqrt{3}, \infty,)\), test point \(x = 2\)

\[\begin{aligned} f''(2) = \frac{2(2)((2)^2 -3)}{({2}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{4}{5^3} > 0\end{aligned}\]

Filling in the table yields:

[c]@llllllll@ & \((-\infty,r_1)\) & r1 & \(\displaystyle (r_1,r_2)\) & r2 & \(\displaystyle (r_2,r_3)\) & r3 & \((r_3,\infty)\)
\(f\)(x)” & - & 0 & + & 0 & - & 0 & +
sols_raw:
Before taking derivatives, we will fill in the first table, by testing values in the two intervals listed.  

Note that <math>x^2 + 1</math> will always be positive, so when calculating whether the function/derivatives are positive or negative, it is sufficient to look at the numerator as the denominator will always be positive.

* <math>(-\infty, 0)</math>, test point <math>x = -1</math>

:: <math>f(-1) = \frac{-1}{(-1)^2 + 1} = \frac{-1}{2} < 0 </math>

* <math>(0, \infty)</math>, test point <math>x = 1</math>

:: <math>f(1) = \frac{1}{(1)^2 + 1} = \frac{1}{2} > 0 </math>

So the first table should be filled in as: 

{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;"
|-
| || <math>(-\infty,0)</math> || 0 || <math> (0,\infty) </math>
|-
| ''&fnof;(x)'' || - || 0 || +
|}



Proceeding to the second table, we will calculate the first derivative using the quotient rule: 

<math>f'(x) = \frac{1*(x^2 + 1) - x(2x)}{(x^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{1 - x^2}{(x^2 + 1)^2}</math>

Setting equal to zero and solving for ''x'' gives: 

<math>\displaystyle 0 = 1 - x^2</math> 

That is, <math> \displaystyle x = -1</math>, <math>\displaystyle x = 1</math>.  These are then our values for <math>c_1</math> and <math>c_2</math>.  We can now test points in the three intervals labeled in the table.  

* <math>(-\infty, -1)</math>, test point <math>x = -2</math>

:: <math>f'(-2) = \frac{1 - (-2)^2}{((-2)^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{-3}{25} < 0</math>

* <math>(-1,1)</math>, test point <math>x = 0</math>

:: <math>f'(0) = \frac{1 - (0)^2}{((0)^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{1}{1} > 0</math>

* <math>(1, \infty)</math>, test point <math>x = 2</math>

:: <math>f'(2) = \frac{1 - (2)^2}{((2)^2 + 1)^2} = \frac{-3}{25} < 0</math>

Filling in the table should look like this: 

{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;"
|-
| || <math>(-\infty,c_1)</math> || ''c<sub>1</sub>'' || <math>\displaystyle (c_1,c_2) </math> || ''c<sub>2</sub>'' || <math> (c_2,\infty) </math>
|-
| ''&fnof;'(x)'' || - || 0 || + || 0 || - 
|}


Finally, we compute the second derivative, again using the quotient rule:

<math>\begin{align}
f''(x) &= \frac{-2x(x^2 + 1)^2 - (1-x^2)(2)(x^2 + 1)(2x)}{(x^2 + 1)^4} \\
&= \frac{-2x(x^2 + 1) -(1-x^2)(4x)}{(x^2 + 1)^3} \\
&= \frac{-2x^3 -2x -4x+4x^3}{(x^2 + 1)^3} \\
&= \frac{2x^3 -6x}{(x^2 + 1)^3} \\
&= \frac{2x(x^2-3)}{(x^2 + 1)^3}
\end{align}</math>

Again solving for where <math>\displaystyle f''(x) = 0</math> we have

<math>\displaystyle 0 = 2x(x^2 - 3)</math>

which yields critical points of <math>x = -\sqrt{3}, x = 0</math> and <math>x = \sqrt{3}</math>, which will be <math>r_1, r_2, r_3</math> respectively.  When testing points in each of the four intervals of the table, it is worth noting that <math>\sqrt{3}</math> is somewhere between 1 and 2.  

* <math>(-\infty, -\sqrt{3})</math>, test point <math>x = -2</math>

:: <math>f''(-2) = \frac{2(-2)((-2)^2 -3)}{({-2}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{-4}{5^3} < 0</math>

* <math>(-\sqrt{3}, 0)</math>, test point <math>x = -1</math>

:: <math>f''(-1) = \frac{2(-1)((-1)^2 - 3)}{({-1}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{4}{2^3} > 0</math>

* <math>(0, \sqrt{3})</math>, test point <math>x = 1</math>

:: <math>f''(1) = \frac{2(1)((1)^2 -3)}{({1}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{-4}{2^3} < 0</math>

* <math>(\sqrt{3}, \infty,)</math>, test point <math>x = 2</math>

:: <math>f''(2) = \frac{2(2)((2)^2 -3)}{({2}^2 + 1)^3} = \frac{4}{5^3} > 0</math>

Filling in the table yields: 

{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;"
|-
| || <math>(-\infty,r_1)</math> || ''r<sub>1</sub>'' || <math>\displaystyle (r_1,r_2) </math> || ''r<sub>2</sub>'' || <math>\displaystyle (r_2,r_3) </math> || ''r<sub>3</sub>'' || <math> (r_3,\infty) </math>
|-
| ''&fnof;''(x)'' || - || 0 || + || 0 || - || 0 || +
|}
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{x}{x^2+1}\end{aligned}\]

defined on the whole real line.

The zeros of \(f'\), increasing order, are c1 = ___ and c2 = ___.

The zeros of \(f''\), in increasing order, are r1 = ___, r2 = ___ and r3 = ___.

In each empty cell of the tables below, enter a + or - to indicate sign of \(f\), \(f'\) and \(f''\) as appropriate.

[c]@llll@ & \((-\infty,0)\) & 0 & \((0,\infty)\)
\(f(x)\) & & 0 &

[c]@llllll@ & \((-\infty,c_1)\) & c1 & \(\displaystyle (c_1,c_2)\) & c2 & \((c_2,\infty)\)
\(f'(x)\) & & 0 & & 0 &

[c]@llllllll@ & \((-\infty,r_1)\) & r1 & \(\displaystyle (r_1,r_2)\) & r2 & \(\displaystyle (r_2,r_3)\) & r3 & \((r_3,\infty)\)
\(f''(x)\) & & 0 & & 0 & & 0 &

:<math>
f(x) = \frac{x}{x^2+1}
</math>

defined on the whole real line.

The zeros of <math> \ f ' </math>, increasing order, are ''c<sub>1</sub>'' = ___ and ''c<sub>2</sub>'' = ___.

|-
| <math>\ f'(x)</math> ||  || 0 || || 0 || 
|}

{| class="wikitable"

|-
| <math>\ f''(x)</math> ||  || 0 || || 0 || || 0 ||
